Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: My neighborhood, situated in a large city, is a melting pot of diverse cultures and lifestyles. Amidst the urban landscape, residential areas are scattered throughout the city, intermingling with a wide array of commercial establishments. These businesses encompass everything from offices to various stores, restaurants, and entertainment venues, providing ample options for dining and shopping. While prominent brands and large corporations dominate some of the retail scene, there's a growing trend towards smaller boutiques, which are not only found in malls but also along the streets, often within walking distance of residential areas. The presence of these businesses has transformed what would otherwise be quiet neighborhoods into vibrant hubs of activity. A few nearby parks are also popular gathering spots for families with young children. What's more, my neighborhood boasts an impressive diversity of people, with distinct communities like the LGBTQ+ community, Orthodox Jewish community, and refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union concentrated in specific areas. As one ventures further afield, the city's multiculturalism becomes even more pronounced, with various ethnic enclaves such as Korea town, China town, and Little Armenia, all within a short radius. However, the city's size and notorious traffic congestion can make even short distances feel like a lengthy ordeal, especially during rush hour. Walking is a rare sight, as the city's sprawling nature and reliance on personal vehicles have led to severe traffic congestion and limited parking options. Interestingly, the city has witnessed significant growth in recent years, with numerous high-rise apartment buildings being constructed, which has sparked concerns among residents about the strain on infrastructure and roads. Nevertheless, the city's housing landscape is characterized by a mix of large apartment buildings, single-family homes, smaller apartment buildings, and condominiums, catering to diverse preferences and needs. Moreover, the neighborhood is home to people of various ages, and, as I've found, I'm not familiar with most of my neighbors, despite being a lifelong resident. While the sense of community is somewhat lost in the large city, I still cherish memories of my childhood, when I spent countless hours playing with my next-door neighbor and a handful of friends from the neighborhood, who shared similar ages and interests.

My neighborhood is a unique and nostalgic place to live. It's primarily composed of single-family homes, although a few have been converted into two-part residences, still connected. My house, like many others, features a small front yard and a driveway to the side. The architecture evokes a bygone era when suburban living was the epitome of the American dream. While this ideal once seemed to unite people, it now appears to be slipping away. However, my neighborhood and others like it still embody the essence of this dream, even if the community's vibrancy has diminished. The residents, though less optimistic than in the past, still cling to the idea of this dream. Evidence of this can be seen in the well-maintained cars in every driveway and the kids' carefree playfulness, as if the world revolves solely around them. The local public school, which has been a staple for nearly a century, continues to inspire the youth while stirring nostalgia in the older residents. The few churches that remain are largely empty, but the basketball courts are always bustling. Despite the varying appearances of the homes, they share a common character. The neighborhood is home to a notable supermarket, Super "A", which has been family-owned by a Yemeni family for years. The majority of residents are African American, and the streets are wide, often used for kids to play football. Many long-time residents have established deep roots in the community, and their stories reflect a time when everyone knew each other. In the past, there was a karate school, but its decline coincided with the waning popularity of karate movies. It's now a pharmacy, a testament to the notion that modern medicine is often seen as a solution to life's problems. Another notable feature is the small, old movie theater, which screens classic films at discounted prices. Although it's not as popular with the youth, who prefer new releases, it remains a beloved destination for the older residents, who see it as a budget-friendly way to enjoy a night out. The town is bounded by a major expressway, which passes through the adjacent town, not our own. A petition to install an exit within our town was proposed, but ultimately rejected by the city council after the older residents expressed concerns that it would compromise the town's character. The construction of a new high school is underway, and the community is currently debating the perfect mascot to represent the town. I believe a cyborg with a country accent, living in a log cabin, would be an apt and humorous representation of our community.

At first glance, it's easy to overlook this residential area, nestled behind a shopping strip, as it doesn't seem to be a place where people would typically want to live. However, if you look beyond the abandoned Whole Foods and the annually occupied hotels, you'll discover a thriving community. Behind these buildings, a series of apartment complexes are situated side by side, much like intricately arranged Russian nesting dolls. While one complex has received negative attention, the adjacent ones are a different story altogether, a hidden world that remains largely unknown to area residents. Across from these complexes is a community college campus, a quiet, sleepy group of buildings where students begin their day with a morning coffee, exchanging sleepy greetings with one another. The entrance gates creak open, allowing students to enter while commuters outside express frustration at the traffic congestion on busy days. The road intersects with another residential street, lined with a park and a rehabilitation center that provides care for individuals with broken bones. The center boasts a welcoming atmosphere, complete with cozy outdoor furniture and a ceiling fan that gently circulates the warm summer air. Children play freely in the park, laughing and playing tag among the tall, green grass while bees flit about the nearby flowers. Retired individuals stroll along the walking path, occasionally scolding teenagers skateboarding by while nodding at groups of teenage girls chatting by the playground equipment. A sushi restaurant, a swimming supply store, and a nail salon are situated in a nearby strip mall, offering a unique combination of services and amenities. Residents can even fill their pool while getting a manicure and enjoying a meal at the hibachi restaurant, highlighting the convenience of this strip mall. A frozen yogurt shop with DIY toppings is also located in the area, and it's not uncommon to see teenagers enjoying frozen yogurt and performing tricks on their skateboards, often accompanied by vaping. This neighborhood is a quintessential representation of small-town America, a staple in the sleepy southern region where time seems to stand still.

As we drove past the endless cornfields that stretched as far as the eye could see, she asked in amazement, "Where is everything?" I smiled knowingly, anticipating her reaction to the vast, open landscape. She was accustomed to living in a town where the grocery store was within a five-minute walk from her house, having never seen such an expansive area before. I took the opportunity to share with her what it was like growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally gained insight into my background. As we continued down the two-lane country road, we passed by a quarry filled with water, followed by the small development where I reside. The neighborhood homes were predominantly made of brick and stucco, each boasting a half-acre of private land that residents take great pride in maintaining. The area comes alive during springtime, with beautifully planted flowers and midwestern trees that change colors with the seasons. The driveways were lined with luxury Mercedes Benz cars, glistening in the sunlight after a good wash. Along the way, we met my neighbor, a friendly Korean man who spends his days mowing his lawn and singing along to the sound of his lawnmower. His genuine nature and unique past as a doctor make him a beloved figure in the neighborhood, and his slight decline in wit due to aging only adds to his charm. As we approached my home, we were greeted by a lively atmosphere: geese roaming the side yard and our energetic Terrier chasing them, while the sound of a nearby stream and bullfrogs created a soothing background noise. A small wooden bridge led to an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers, where I spent much of my childhood. I spent hours building treehouses, playing 'hunting' games, and making friends with the neighborhood kids. Although our town's winters can be harsh, they hold a special beauty, as the yard transforms into a barren landscape, and the trees, once teeming with colorful flowers, stand as bare skeletons. The occasional snowfall brings a magical transformation, turning the backyard into a winter wonderland with snow angels, snowmen, and a peaceful atmosphere. My sister and I often engaged in friendly battles, using snowballs as our primary weapon, and built elaborate forts with branches to serve as our arsenals. In this idyllic setting, my sister and I would play pretend, free from the worries of the world, just like carefree children.

To truly grasp Portland, Oregon, one must understand the essence of "weirdness." The unofficial town motto, "Keep Portland Weird," emblazoned on a building that serves multiple purposes, reflects the city's eclectic nature. This phrase resonates with some as a nostalgic reminder of Portland's past, when it was a lesser-known, more affordable gem that birthed unique and creative subcultures. For others, it's an invitation to visit a place where individuality is celebrated, even encouraged. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the construction of new condominiums to accommodate them, Portland's eccentricity remains intact. While it may not always be open-minded, "weird" in Portland means embracing the unconventional, the things that don't conform to societal norms. The city isn't devoid of modern comforts or amenities; we still buy many of our goods from China, just like the rest of the country. There's no one-size-fits-all definition of "weird," as Portland has a diverse range of lifestyles and subcultures, from yogis and hipsters to business professionals. Perhaps what makes Portland unique is that we take life less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many others, you can find vibrant houses, community gardens, and a tradition of free boxes filled with unexpected treasures during the summer months. These free boxes often contain second-hand items, but they can hold anything, and they add to the city's charm. For those of us who appreciate this aspect of Portland, it's a big part of what makes the city special. However, not everyone shares the same values; some would never dream of rummaging through free boxes, opting instead for more unconventional activities like goat yoga or watching the local soccer team play. Portland is a melting pot of people with diverse interests and passions. While the city struggles with issues like substance abuse and homelessness, which are often linked to underlying mental health problems, it's clear that these challenges aren't what define Portland's essence. The city's approach to social services is admirable, but it's insufficient, a problem common to many areas of the country. The city's residents are torn between empathy and frustration, a sentiment that's all too familiar elsewhere. In this regard, Portland is more ordinary than weird.

The mountains stand steadfast in the north, a constant presence that bears witness to the sun's daily journey, remaining unchanged amidst life's turmoil. Even when I become consumed by work and daily life, forgetting their existence, they remain unfazed, waiting for me to acknowledge them. On my most stressful and anxious days, they invite me to take notice, offering solace and fortifying me to carry on, one day at a time. My connection to this place began when I started college, and the mountains north of campus were the first to capture my heart. Although the university has its own breathtaking landscapes, such as its buildings, ponds, and trees, the mountains hold a special place in my affections. The rest of the town is charming in its own right, with quaint cafés where I spent many hours studying and people-watching over cups of coffee. Downtown, a short walk or bus ride away, exudes an aura of history with its faded, colorful brick buildings, giving the town a unique blend of suburban tranquility and urban vibrancy. This dichotomy of atmosphere creates a captivating ambiance that tempts exploration. As a result, I've accumulated numerous cherished memories associated with different parts of town, such as strolling with friends through the park after an all-nighter or racing through the busy downtown to catch a movie. However, I've also experienced difficult memories, a natural aspect of life. The town's ponds have served as a refuge for introspection and emotional catharsis during my late-night existential crises. While watching the turtles, ducks, and other creatures live their lives, I couldn't help but ponder my own purpose and navigate the complexities of life. As I walked past the pond, park, and suburban houses, I eventually reached a main street where the sun broke through the clouds, casting a warm glow on the palm trees and sky. Gazing up at the sunrise, I noticed I was walking north, and the mountains, as they had always been, stood tall and majestic, stretching across the horizon. Their presence stirred in me a sense of resilience and determination.

If you're planning a trip to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, you'll find it quite easily accessible thanks to the abundant public transportation options available. As a primarily urban neighborhood, Bensonhurst embodies the character of New York City. During your visit, you can expect to see a high concentration of Asian-owned stores, which have become a dominant feature of the area over the last two decades. This influx of Asian residents has led to the proliferation of Asian-owned stores, with supermarkets and laundromats being particularly common. These businesses are in high demand among locals due to their excellent quality, affordable prices, and convenient locations. I'm surrounded by four Asian supermarkets within a short two-minute walk of each other, making it incredibly convenient to access grocery shopping.

While Bensonhurst is predominantly Asian, it's not the only demographic present in the area. The neighborhood boasts a diverse population of immigrants and their American-born children, with many large local businesses owned by Asian entrepreneurs. Visitors can also enjoy the recently renovated park, which offers a range of facilities, including basketball courts, a sports field, handball courts, playgrounds, and a water fountain for kids. The parks in New York City are known for their diversity, and this one is no exception. The neighborhood's residential landscape is characterized by co-op living buildings and condominium apartments, with two-family houses being the most prevalent type of dwelling. The locals are generally friendly, but be prepared for a lively atmosphere, with cars often blasting music and speeding by, which can be both noisy and disrupt your morning routine. When visiting at night, it's essential to be mindful of your surroundings, as petty crime can occur. While the area is generally safe, there have been instances of bullying and package theft in the past. Lastly, be prepared to encounter dog waste on the streets, as some residents fail to follow the city's rules on pet waste disposal. It's essential to maintain your personal space and keep your shoes clean when walking around the neighborhood.

The lack of sidewalks in my area is quite noticeable, as everything seems to slope downward. My house is situated at the top of the steepest hill in the neighborhood, an area locals affectionately call the "workout hill" due to the numerous joggers who train on it daily. As a result of the absence of sidewalks on my street, pedestrians are forced to walk on the road, which can be hazardous due to its pitted surface. The area is also home to exposed telephone and electric wires, which appear worn and weathered due to frequent storm damage and subsequent repairs. The neighborhood is surrounded by dense evergreen trees, but residents often prioritize removing them to preserve the ocean views. Consequently, many houses are built on the hillside, with expansive second-story glass facades to showcase the bay's scenery. During sunset, the water takes on a warm, golden hue as the sky transitions to orange, although the prevailing overcast weather often obscures the sun's full radiance. The damp, misty atmosphere fosters the growth of moss on rooftops, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked for an extended period, only to find it had become a moss-covered, furry landscape that required hours to clean. In contrast to the nearby school, my neighborhood is predominantly inhabited by older residents, many of whom are retired. While children are scarce, dogs are a common sight, often roaming freely in front yards or racing down the street. Leaving doors or windows open can be a recipe for unwanted canine visitors; in fact, I once discovered one in my living room and had to gently escort it back outside. Rabbits are another familiar presence, but gardeners view them as pests due to their tendency to uproot plants and burrow into lawns. My cats, on the other hand, have developed a taste for hunting them. The area also attracts a typical assortment of birds, including sparrows, hummingbirds, and occasional hawks, which are often chased away by the neighborhood crows. For those seeking amenities, a short hike downhill leads to waterfront restaurants serving fresh seafood, although the beach itself is relatively narrow, and the rocks along the shore offer a fun spot for skipping stones. The bay's relatively narrow width makes it possible to see the opposite shoreline even on overcast days.

I reside in a typical suburban area within a small town in the southern state of Tennessee. The street I live on is a connecting route between two state highways, resulting in moderate traffic levels, but the neighborhood itself remains relatively quiet. Since the area experiences limited residential turnover, I have become familiar with most of the long-term residents. People generally spend their time engaged in household chores and yard work. In the winter, our side street transforms into a popular sledding spot. As we reside at the front corner of our street, we're exposed to a constant flow of neighbors and familiarize ourselves with their vehicles. Whenever we encounter unfamiliar vehicles, we take notice. Some neighbors prioritize walking for exercise or stroll their dogs, while children enjoy riding their bikes, reflecting the typical suburban atmosphere. Given that we work from home with my wife and two daughters (ages 11 and 14), our presence is well-known to the neighbors. We often spend time outside, even on rainy days, and occasionally host barbecues on our back deck, filling the air with the pleasant aroma of grilled food. The neighborhood's original wooded landscape has resulted in an abundance of trees, providing adequate shade but also necessitating annual leaf raking and burning. I find the scent of burning leaves invigorating, signaling the arrival of autumn. Lately, the winters have been mild, which has prolonged our autumn season. Our attached garage, located at the rear of our house, is rarely used as an entry point, except when someone knocks on the door, a rare occurrence. I enjoy working on my truck and other projects within the garage, which allows me to stay connected to the neighborhood atmosphere. During holidays like Thanksgiving and Christmas, the neighborhood comes alive with visiting family members from out of town, resulting in increased car traffic. Overall, I am content with living in this area, but if it weren't a through street, it would be ideal.

I reside in a neighborhood situated in the heart of the high desert, surrounded by vast expanses of arid land. Unless one has personal experience living here, it's challenging to grasp the sheer ubiquity of brown hues that dominate the landscape. However, the occasional sight of lush lawns is a stark contrast, and it becomes apparent that maintaining such a landscape comes with a hefty price tag. When I first moved here in the 1990s, the houses were scattered and spacious. Although the area has seen a surge in new developments, its layout still resembles a rural setting. As with any community, there are both positive and negative aspects to living in this neighborhood. I'm fortunate to be surrounded by friendly elderly residents, which contributes to its pleasant atmosphere. The local shops mainly comprise chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. For specialty items, such as organic or upscale products, residents often need to venture further afield. In my city, the primary sources of employment seem to be construction-related, likely due to the area's relatively undeveloped state and the abundance of open spaces available for building. This rapid growth is somewhat unsettling, but as someone who moved from a larger city, I prefer the current pace of life. Notably, my job as a drywall and T-bar installer is directly tied to the construction industry. One of the aspects I appreciate about this area is the diverse wildlife, which has drawn people to the high desert for its unique natural beauty. The harsh desert climate and geography create intricate ecosystems that require protection and are home to a variety of species. It's essential for human residents to learn about and coexist with these non-human inhabitants to preserve the delicate balance of this environment. My family and I have adapted well to the local wildlife, and our children are particularly enthusiastic about observing lizards and desert insects. In fact, as I write this, they're outside attempting to catch specimens. In terms of local attractions, Victorville has some unique offerings. It's an excellent destination for families seeking a desert experience, and planning a visit during the annual San Bernardino County Fair is a great idea. The event provides a delightful blend of activities and entertainment that showcases the community's spirit. Visitors can also explore the nearby Wrightwood, where they can take in the breathtaking views of snow-capped mountains and even participate in winter sports lessons. For those interested in the natural history and cultural heritage of the high desert ecosystem, the Victor Valley Museum offers an impressive collection of geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the region's development and evolution.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'd say my answer is quite distinct from others. While many people who respond to this question are homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a bit different. For me, my neighborhood is the college campus where I reside, and the people living in my dorm are my community. I also consider the surrounding campus as a part of my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this unique perspective, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with traditional ideas of a neighborhood. Like any conventional neighborhood, mine has houses, residents, shops, and parks. Let's start by exploring the "houses" that make up my neighborhood. To provide some context, there are three types of housing in my immediate area: apartments, houses, and dormitory-style housing. Firstly, apartments typically accommodate 2-4 people per room, with 4-6 rooms on each floor. A standard building can house around 20 individuals. Secondly, there are houses available for rent, usually with 2-4 bedrooms and often occupied by alumni. However, these are relatively scarce due to their inefficiency. Lastly, there are the dorm rooms, which can house hundreds of students, with some exceptions where two people share a room. This is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. Now that we've covered housing, let's move on to the people. My school emphasizes diversity, and this is reflected in the neighborhood's demographics. There's a wide range of cultures and ages represented, with professional staff residing in houses and newer students in dorms, while older students live in apartments. As the neighborhood is essentially a self-contained community, it boasts a variety of stores and a single park. The stores offer a mix of dining options and the school's unique products, ensuring that everything needed can be found within the neighborhood's boundaries. The park serves as a playground for the diverse community, maintained and safe due to the collective efforts of its members.

It's been about 10 years since I moved to my current neighborhood, and as I reflect on my experiences, I've come to appreciate the place more. At first, I was quite sad when I left Riverdale for Stockbridge, as I had strong ties there. However, my parents made the decision to relocate to a better area for our housing, education, and overall quality of life. Over time, I grew accustomed to my new surroundings, formed new friendships, and encountered some acquaintances who turned out to be adversaries. Despite not getting to know many of my neighbors well, there were a few families who stood out to me, particularly the Glems and the Dennises, who lived right next door. They've been kind and welcoming, and I consider them to be like an extended family. I vividly remember attending Mr. Glen's wedding, which was a wonderful experience, and I'm looking forward to the day I can give my future partner the same kind of celebration. One memorable moment from the wedding was when Ms. Veda threw her wedding garter, and I managed to catch it, although I missed catching the bouquet. The neighborhood can be a bit confusing, but with the help of a GPS, I've started to explore it more. I've had some enjoyable times with friends, like Kason and Curtis, where we'd spend hours playing video games and making the most of our time together. I also appreciate the local park, which provides a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of daily life. I often visit the park to clear my mind and enjoy nature. You can find me there practicing my balance with some sticks from Home Depot or wielding my bokken wooden sword. It's great to have a basketball and tennis court nearby, even if I haven't played those sports in a while. My dad and I used to spend hours playing tennis with Mr. Graves when I was younger, and those were some of my fondest memories. Looking back, I've had many wonderful experiences in this neighborhood, and I'm excited to see what the future holds.

Living near my college has made my neighborhood a convenient and enjoyable place to reside. The area is primarily made up of apartment buildings, which are complemented by a few affordable restaurants and bars that offer a fun atmosphere without breaking the bank. However, one of the bars has recently undergone a name change, and while it's now pricier, the service and drinks are still satisfactory. The neighborhood's demographics consist mainly of students and lower-income residents due to the relatively low cost of apartment housing. The presence of an elementary school within walking distance contributes to a lively atmosphere, as there are many children in the area. Despite not knowing my neighbors particularly well, I've developed a certain understanding of them - they predominantly smoke marijuana, and the management of my building has installed an air purifier outside their door, which my boyfriend and I find amusing. 

The surrounding buildings, although old in appearance, might have undergone renovations, giving them a more modern interior. Nearby, there are newly constructed apartments, but I'm not a fan of them because I'm concerned about their cheap construction and high rent prices, which I believe is unfair given their proximity to the campus. Furthermore, a local eatery, just a five-minute walk from my residence, serves meals on paper plates and primarily microwaves their dishes. Across from this eatery is a gas station, which I've heard is a less-than-desirable place to work. However, a recent city-funded renovation project has improved the road conditions, leaving a wider sidewalk, lush greenery on the medians and road sides, and a more pleasant overall atmosphere. 

My apartment building is actually surrounded by trees, although a few were recently cut down, leaving stumps behind. In contrast, the area behind my complex is lined with trees, and another apartment complex is situated beyond that. Although I reside on 42nd street, the adjacent 43rd street is less desirable, with crumbling sidewalks and dilapidated buildings. This street does have a lot of trees, which might be an attempt to conceal its poor appearance. Many of the crimes in my area have been reported at a nearby apartment complex, but it's worth noting that other apartments across the street also have a history of crime and a transient population. Despite these issues, I'm content with my living situation, as I can afford it and have access to various amenities, including a nearby university and two convenient bus stops that make it easy to get to the store or downtown.

My neighborhood is comprised of a series of duplexes situated on a cul-de-sac, which are carefully placed to give the appearance of individual homes. The main distinguishing feature of each duplex is its yellow exterior with white porches and green metal roofs. While not everyone is acquainted, the majority of residents have a friendly relationship with one another. On certain evenings, we gather at the end of the shared driveway and engage in casual conversations while children play with their toys, color with sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. This idyllic atmosphere offers a refreshing respite from the fast-paced, technology-driven world we live in, evoking a sense of stepping back in time. The neighborhood is surrounded by lush fields, trees, and an open sky with puffy white clouds. However, we've recently experienced our first tornado warning and actual tornado sirens, prompting us to seek shelter. On that occasion, I found myself in the bathtub with my pet, a purse, and a few pillows, while my larger dog remained in the living room, nervously barking. The neighborhood was eerily quiet, except for the sound of hail pounding against the ground. Following the storm, the temperature dropped dramatically, causing the road to steam, and the hail instantly melted upon hitting the hot pavement. As the skies cleared, the sun reappeared, and a double rainbow materialized. I quickly ran to grab my camera and captured the breathtaking sight to share with my friends and family on Facebook. The neighborhood remained quiet for a while, until residents began to return home from wherever they had been when the storm struck. Once the storm passed, life returned to normal, with mothers and children resuming their evening routines while dinner cooked. As a newcomer to the area, having recently moved from New Hampshire to North Carolina, I'm grateful to have found this welcoming community. I particularly appreciate the warm, soothing southern accent of the locals. Although my two-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment may be similar in appearance to others, each unit has its unique character. Some are surprisingly compact, and I struggle to understand why this is the case. I enjoy taking leisurely walks through the large field behind my home, often making my way to the nearby pond, which is not intended for swimming. During my strolls, I've spotted deer and have been treated to the melodic song of a bullfrog in the mornings. This is a truly wonderful place to live, located just a 40-minute drive from the city of Charlotte. Each morning is greeted by the cheerful sound of roosters crowing from the surrounding farms, giving our community a quaint, rural feel. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that brays in the evenings, serving as a friendly reminder of his presence. I feel fortunate to have discovered this charming neighborhood.

I moved to my current neighborhood just before starting eighth grade, which made it challenging for me to make friends initially. However, I eventually formed close bonds with two of my neighbors - one living two houses down from me and the other on the same street. Although they've since moved away, the memories we shared remain vivid. Interestingly, the people who resided here when I first moved in are still largely present in the neighborhood today. My neighborhood is typical of many American suburban areas, characterized by two-story houses. You often hear the sound of children playing outdoors on weekends and warm days, and it's usually quiet most weekdays. I've always had a positive experience with my neighbors, and I feel confident in their reliability. On more than one occasion, I've ordered online packages without incident, which is a testament to the trust I have in my community. There's a park just a short walk away from my house, which holds a special place in my heart. I've spent countless hours there playing sports with my neighbors and, sadly, also experienced a painful memory when I got elbowed in the nose during a game. Nevertheless, the good times I've had at the park far outweigh the bad. Now, whenever I visit the park, I enjoy quality time with my younger cousin's children, watching them enjoy the swings and slides. This nostalgia is a result of many fond memories I've formed in the park. The neighborhood is quite diverse, offering a variety of cuisines within a short radius. You can easily find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants within a one-mile radius, although many people now prefer using food delivery apps. Conveniently, there are also plenty of fast-food options and pizza places nearby. The local stores cater to all your needs, with multiple dry cleaners, a Walgreens, a CVS, and a Jewel-Osco grocery store - a popular Midwestern chain. Some stores even offer culturally diverse products, such as an Indian-owned shop where you can purchase ingredients for homemade Indian dishes or ready-made meals. Overall, I'm grateful for my neighborhood and feel fortunate to live in a community where I've never experienced any issues with my neighbors. Reading about others' struggles with their neighbors on social media and in the news only reinforces my appreciation for mine.

My neighborhood is a small, unassuming town in South Carolina that plays a significant role in the region's agricultural sector. Dubbed the "Peach Capital of the World," Johnston takes pride in its claim to fame, proudly displayed on a welcoming sign. The town's landscape is predominantly made up of farmland, with peach trees and cattle being the main features. Houses in the surrounding areas are spaced out, typically two-story structures with metal or gray roofs to withstand the hot summer weather. Many of these homes are situated away from the main road, allowing for the front fields to be used for animal grazing and crop cultivation. In the town center, there is a single stoplight at a four-way intersection, where residents can find a limited selection of stores. Options include a family-run Chinese restaurant, a Mexican eatery, a small burger joint, and a pharmacy famous for its Cherry Coke. The town's grocery store, IGA, is small and relatively expensive, with many residents opting to shop at a Walmart in a nearby town instead. In contrast, the Dollar General store is a hub of activity, offering a wide range of everyday essentials. The town also boasts a long-standing furniture store, a pet grooming service, and a pair of small medical practices. Johnston Elementary School is the only school in the town, with students attending middle and high school in the neighboring town after completing the fifth grade. The town is currently working on developing a 2.5-acre recreational area to provide residents with more opportunities for outdoor activities and attract new visitors. While it lacks amenities like movie theaters, playgrounds, and a variety of restaurants, Johnston remains a charming town that can easily be overlooked.

At first, I became aware of my neighborhood through a podcast that discussed individuals who had gone missing. It caught me off guard, especially considering that almost every apartment in the area had a rental price exceeding $1000 a month. I was surprised that I'd never heard about it before, and neither had any of my acquaintances. This might be a result of the challenges we face in daily life, where many people struggle to make ends meet. I'm familiar with the financial struggles, as I've seen some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night due to the high cost of living. However, over the years, we've learned to be thrifty and appreciate the simple things in life. The smell of second-hand items and worn clothes is something you grow accustomed to, and it's a far cry from the scent of adulthood, which is more reminiscent of dusty magazines and aged leather. It's a smell that lingers even after thorough cleaning. My neighborhood is a treasure trove of thrift stores, with three within walking distance. You can explore charity thrift stores, a library, a rare bookshop, and a curiosity shop if you start on one end. The downtown area is bustling, with cars and pedestrians filling the streets in the morning, but you wouldn't know it from the thrift stores, which remain remarkably quiet. It's a peaceful place to spend an afternoon, sheltered from the outside world. As the city continues to grow, with one of the largest e-commerce and delivery empires based here, it's still experiencing growing pains, much like a developing New York City. Everyone seems to be focused on their individual goals, with little expectation of interference from others. It's easy to be alone, quiet, and independent, and people tend to respect that. In contrast to the South, where being concerned for someone's well-being is seen as a sign of caring, this city values personal space. You're free to maintain your shell as long as you like, and the city will adapt to your needs, much like the ebb and flow of waves on the beach. This city is vibrant, with music drifting from the pianist next door and the amateur vocalists upstairs. It's more like a community of friends than a collection of strangers, where we come together for support, celebrations, and times of grief. I feel fortunate to be part of this community, as I get along with my neighbors and they treat me with kindness. We look out for each other, sharing food and mail, and I appreciate their company as much as they seem to appreciate mine. In the midst of a massive, impersonal modernist development, it's the people like my neighbors who make me feel like I haven't completely compromised my life.

I live in a conventional suburban area, characterized by a uniformity that's typical of cookie-cutter neighborhoods. The presence of a homeowner's association (HOA) is evident in my community. The neighborhood is filled with well-maintained single-family homes, thanks to the HOA's efforts. Each property features a standardized arrangement of landscaped grass, decorative pebbles, and short driveways. The occasional tree adds some visual interest, while two-car garages are a common feature. The streets are in excellent condition, with newly paved concrete and no potholes to be found. While most homes are single-story, two-story houses can be spotted here and there. The neighborhood's mail system deviates from the typical setup, with a communal mailbox cluster at the end of each street accessible via a key. Package storage is also available in secured lockers. The HOA's emphasis on uniformity is likely responsible for this arrangement.

My house is situated on the outskirts of the nearby city, making our neighborhood a blend of rural and suburban characteristics. This unique location provides ample space for residents to enjoy various amenities, including multiple community pools that are well-maintained and gated. Walking trails allow for leisurely strolls or dog walks, eliminating the need to visit a park for exercise. The neighborhood's size enables residents to get a good workout by simply walking or jogging around it. While retirees make up the majority of the community, there's also a smaller population of middle-aged and young professionals. Our area is known for being safe, with a strong sense of camaraderie among residents. The nearby city is surprisingly large in terms of population but has a small-town feel. It offers a wide range of amenities, including a single mall that may not be massive but meets our needs. Major stores are within a 15-minute drive, offering a variety of options, from high-end grocery stores to discounted outlets. Overall, my neighborhood is a safe, well-maintained, and fairly typical community with many desirable features like pools and walking trails. While it's not adjacent to shopping centers, accessing major chains is easy with a short drive.

I reside in a small Midwestern town situated just beyond the suburban boundaries of a major metropolitan area. The neighborhood on the town's east side, where I live, is characterized as the most economically disadvantaged area within the community. Property values in this area are relatively low, and most homes are occupied by individuals with limited financial resources. Despite this, the neighborhood is not unappealing, and the residents are generally friendly and welcoming. They often exchange smiles and greetings when passing by. Although crime rates in this area are slightly higher than in other parts of town, they remain relatively low. However, there have been instances of violent crimes in the nearby vicinity over the past decade, including shootings and a homicide. Our next-door neighbors recently suffered a devastating loss when their son was fatally shot outside a local bar. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime, except for occasional petty thefts when we leave items unattended on our porch. The town as a whole has been significantly impacted by the nationwide "opioid epidemic," which has led to numerous fatalities due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, the town has implemented various initiatives to combat this issue, including addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those struggling with addiction. Despite the challenges, the town boasts several redeeming qualities. My son's elementary school has an excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff, who have created a positive and inclusive environment. This has allowed my child with special needs to feel safe and accepted, and he genuinely enjoys attending school. The Parent-Teacher Organization (PTO) is active and organizes various events throughout the year to foster family involvement and educational progress. Given that over 20% of the town's population lives below the poverty line, the elementary school offers free meals to all students, ensuring that no child goes hungry. The school's policies also make it possible for every family to participate, regardless of financial constraints. The City Council and municipal staff have made significant improvements to the town's infrastructure, including road repavement, landscaping, and park revitalization. However, these upgrades have mainly been focused on the central business district and the west side, where most commercial areas and traffic are concentrated. In contrast, the east side, where I reside, tends to be neglected, which is a source of frustration for local residents. Despite these issues, I find joy in living in this town. The people are generally kind, the schools are excellent, there are sufficient shopping options to meet our needs, and our home, although modest, is comfortable and suitable for our family. We have been living in this town for over 16 years and cannot imagine calling any other place home.

My neighborhood is rich in cultural heritage, situated on a hill surrounded by historic buildings. The seven-story apartment building where I reside is located conveniently close to a vintage theater and a unique arcade bar that attracts diverse crowds on warm summer evenings. The bar is often packed, especially during the weekends in June and July, with people lining up to get in. A short walk away lies the local park, which is remarkably large considering its location in the city. The park is encircled by concrete with stairs integrated into the walls. During the harsh winter months, people experiencing homelessness set up their temporary shelters along the sidewalk and stairs, creating a sense of community and warmth by clustering together. By staying near the city center, they are not only closer to essential services like the nearby family center but also have easier access to transportation and amenities. However, it's not the historic architecture or the scenic views of the ocean that I love about my city. It's the people and their culture that make my neighborhood truly special. The story of Hilltop's past is one of turmoil, with tales of gang violence and federal interventions still being shared among residents, including those who have lived here for generations. Despite its reputation as a rough neighborhood, the community has made significant efforts to maintain its cleanliness and care for its environment. The warning to avoid walking alone at night, particularly for those perceived as outsiders, is a lingering reminder of the past, tainted with the undertones of social bias. I believe this warning speaks to the lingering effects of racism and cultural conditioning that still exist in our society. My own experiences have taught me that the Hilltop community is not as intimidating as its reputation suggests. In fact, the people I've met have shown me kindness and compassion, often going out of their way to help me, even when it's not expected. It's a place where strangers offer assistance without hesitation, where business owners are willing to accommodate my needs, and where people see beyond superficial appearances to recognize my inherent value and worth. The Hilltop is more than just a neighborhood to me; it's a place where I feel truly alive, connected, and at home.

I reside in a small town in Michigan, surrounded by the beauty of rural America. The landscape shifts from vast farmland to quaint tourist destinations. Unlike metropolitan areas, my community lacks large retail stores like big-box chains and chain restaurants. To access amenities, residents must rely on driving. Despite this, our location boasts stunning scenery, with two lakes – Lake Michigan and Lake Charlevoix – bordering our town. Every corner offers a spot to dip your toes in the water. The character of our neighborhood reflects the essence of small-town life. Homes are not cookie-cutter constructions, but rather older, unique residences that have been updated or preserved over time. Many of these homes feature basements, and older aluminum siding is a common sight. The neighborhood is a kaleidoscope of colors, with diverse homes and yards. You'll find trampolines, playsets, gardens, and fences for pets, giving the area a quintessential Midwestern feel. Our community is comprised of hardworking individuals who strive to support their families and make a living. On any given day, you'll spot children playing in the streets, people walking dogs, biking, or rollerblading. Neighbors know one another, and it's easy to determine who fits in and who doesn't. The atmosphere is welcoming, with people exchanging friendly smiles and waves. The lawns are meticulously maintained, with neatly trimmed grass and tidy plants. Our neighborhood isn't flashy, but it exudes a sense of tranquility, safety, and wholesomeness. It's a place where families can thrive, with essential services like the sheriff's department, health department, and recycling center nearby. Within walking distance, you'll find baseball and softball fields, where the sounds of lively games fill the air. The small town airport is nearby, and the local ice cream shop and park are equally accessible. My children can easily bike to the park, which is just a short distance away. Overall, this is an exceptional place to call home.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall.
